plants.name: Magnolia Ã— soulangeana
plants.description: A deciduous tree famous for its large, fragrant, tulip-shaped flowers that burst open in early spring before the leaves appear. Its blooms range from white to pink and purple, creating a spectacular floral display.
plants.location: Temperate regions of North America, Europe, and Asia
plants.funFact: Magnolia flowers are considered ancient; fossils dating back 95 million years show similar blooms, predating bees. They are pollinated by beetles.

plants.name: Narcissus pseudonarcissus
plants.description: A species of daffodil with bright yellow, trumpet-shaped flowers that commonly grow in woodlands, meadows, and grasslands. They are among the first wildflowers signaling spring in the Northern Hemisphere.
plants.location: Western Europe, especially UK and Ireland
plants.funFact: Wild daffodils are known to naturalize and can form large colonies in the wild, sometimes marking ancient woodland boundaries.

plants.name: Jacaranda mimosifolia
plants.description: A tropical and subtropical tree noted for its stunning display of violet-blue trumpet-shaped flowers that blanket streets and parks, especially in places like Australia and South America.
plants.location: Subtropical regions like Australia, South America, Southern Africa
plants.funFact: The Jacaranda's striking bloom usually lasts about three to four weeks, and fallen flowers create a beautiful purple carpet on the ground.

plants.name: Erica carnea
plants.description: A low-growing evergreen shrub that blooms in late winter to early spring, forming clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers often seen in alpine and mountainous areas of Europe.
plants.location: Mountainous regions of Central and Southern Europe
plants.funFact: Unlike many other heath species, Erica carnea can tolerate cold winter conditions and often flowers through snow cover.
